This game is like Super Meat boy but with friends. Fun by yourself, but it's better with friends. Some secret levels you NEED a friend to reach. Public multiplayer is pretty dead, but I don't exactly play during steam's peak hours. It's better with people you actually know, anyways. It has online AND/OR local multiplayer, meaning if you have some gamepads lying around you can connect them and have some buddies play with you in your house/their house while you play with some buddies off in Sneedville, all on the same screen and in the same game. If you do decide to play with friends online, be sure to set a password for your lobby. Learned that the hard way. Online multiplayer also seems a bit laggy for the host, but my internet's subpar at best so beware, those with average connections.

Very fun with some minor issues that don't detract too much from the overall game.

reviewText:
This game is a cute little hardcore platformer. If you're a fan of pure platforming, this game is decent, if a bit frustrating at times. It is not on the same level as Super Meat Boy or the I Wanna Be The Guy games, especially with it's lack of any sort of boss battles, but there is still fun to be had here.

I played through this game in co-op with one friend. The 'co-opness' in this game is somewhat nullified by the fact that you can easily kill the other players by jumping on their heads, so you end up just taking turns attempting to complete each stage, making sure you don't both reach the same section at the same time and accidentally kill each other. It can be a bit fun repeatedly killing the other play to vent your frustrations at times, though, and the frustration of dying in this game is mitigated by the fact that your character instantaneously respawns at the start of the stage when you die.

All in all, an okay game if you enjoy hardcore pure platformers.

reviewText:
This game is most comparable to Super Meat Boy in that you'll die hundreds of times trying to beat levels that require very precise platforming. Like Meat Boy, the load times after deaths are non-existent which is a big plus for this type of game. This game's main draw however is the competetive/co-op. I played through most of the game first with a few friends and then I played all the way through solo. The multiplayer surprisingly never gets too frustrating even though most of your deaths come as a direct result of playing with others. Playing with more than 2 players on the last two worlds can seem ridiculously impossible, as I had  a much easier time playing later by myself.

My one complaint is that we encountered a few annoying bugs later in the game. One was a case where momentum didn't reset at a particular point after fans in a level. Not too bad, but slightly annoying. The other bug was on a few levels where the spawn was located on top of the door to the previous level, we would constantly enter that door upon death.

Overall this is a fun party game that includes a few other multiplayer modes alongside adventure, giving it some decent replayability. Worth a couple bucks.

reviewText:
Review on Bloody Trapland
Written By: Rias Gremory

Pros►This game was gifted to me by one of my close friends, I decided to play the singleplayer for around 15 mins to get the feeling for it, and I have to say I enjoy it! The art style and the amount of blood and gore is just simply amazing, a lot of time has been put into the AI (As is quite obvious) The controls are ok, and they can be dealt with accordingly ;). also enjoy the menus, I know that may not be normal, but they are simple, include what you need, and when you need it, it will provide advanced options, (by opening tabs)

Cons►I have had MANY problems with the multiplayer, at first trying to use Hamachi didn't work at all, I couldn't connect to either of my friends, then it worked for one, then cut out as soon as I started to play, next we tried port forwarding (The process where you add the game ports into your internet access) that was just a waste of our time and effort. This may have just been our clients, but I haven't a clue myself, I haven't really seen any 'problems' on google or the steam forums. Moving on swiftly, The controls, having to use the arrow keys were really awkward for me, as I am used to FPS games there WASD is used. There is most likely a way to change them, but I didn't really have the time to check. There was one minor problem, that I couldn't get my head around though, that was the menu not supporting mouse control, this is purely lazy, and more effort could have gone into allowing a mouse to be used in the menu's, but that is the only hiccup I had with the menu's, they may be hard to navigate, but that is fine.

Overall Review►I enjoyed the plat-former/death system, and had a lot of fun jumping around in the air, straight onto the death blocks, but I didn't really seem to achieve much doing so, but I digress, The way the game is layed out is beautiful, and I could spend a lot more time playing this if I had the nerves...

reviewText:
I just had to stop playing this to write a review. And I'm not doing those very often, let alone getting such urgent impulse to actually close the game for it. But this game deserves it... I guess. Well, I'm just an hour in, reached only W3-1 but oh boy, it gives me some sweats – sweats of joy!
Never have I played such a challenging yet achievable plattformer.  Admittedly it's not my preferred genre of choice on my computer, and console gamers could eventually prove me otherwise, but I'm having a blast!

The gameplay is as easy as it gets – jump, run, duck, avoid deadly objects, just don't die reaching the exit. One lvl is merely one screen, no scrolling. One world has ten screens (plus some bonus stages), as far as I can tell, I'm in the last lvl of the 2nd world. For the adventure mode that is. There are also a race and a deathmatch mode which are obviously multiplayer modes. I've only tried adventure so far, as I'm testing candidates for the next local gaming party, but lacking a buddy right now. And this one looks very promising although you might gather a more experienced crowd. Now, it is hard as stated before and on entering a lvl you might think “how I'm ever going to make this?!”. But you are! It may take a while though*g* It's always doable, never unfair. It takes some plattfoming skill and timing. Controls are precise and responsive. Levels are riddled with – well – traps... where some of those aren't visible when you enter a new screen. But you won't succeed on your first attempt anyway... so.
The graphics are – as you can see on the screenshots – retro styled, inspired by the 16 bit era. They're not particularly unique, but by no means dull or ugly. The gore effect which covers the environment with more and more blood as you're being constantly crushed by the fist of doom or saw blade of horror gives a weird sense of accomplishment. It's got a great soundtrack, I don't like the soundeffects though. Often they don't fit or sound awfully generic.

I definitely recommend Bloody Trapland for solo players and I will vote for it on the next game night with friends.

reviewText:
First off, the game has an amazing soundtrack in my opinion. Try looking up World 3's theme on Youtube if you want. It's by far my favorite. Now, onto more gameplay-related things:

A possible friendship destroyer if you've got that friend who loves to jump on your head and then commit suicide at the end of the level that took you 30 minutes to beat.

Even if you lack any friends to play it with, there's still usually one or two unlocked rooms you can join and make some more friends in. 10 people who I am now friends with on Steam came from random open servers in this game.

The way I see it, this can either be classified as one of three things: an unfair platformer (troll blocks), an impossible platformer (speed run challenges in race mode that are far more difficult than they should be), or a good time (watching friends rage out).

If you're an achievement hunter, this game might not be for you because of the speed run challenges. They're all possible (personal experience), but you best be willing to devote a lot of time and accept a lot of failure to do so.

There's one or two levels that have a bug or two in them, but the game has over 60 campaign levels and 60 more race levels, so the vast majority of levels are bug-free. Some of them even have extremely cheap tactics to complete if you have a friend.

Overall, this game is definitely one of my favorite platformers, but it's no walk in the park on the first playthrough.

Before you buy this game, there are a few things you should take note of.
This game has flaws. Many of them. a low resolution and bad speedrunning system are only the tip of the iceberg.
While this game has lots of flaws, somehow this game manages to be just great. I have found myself to be in love with the soundtrack of this game, some of the multiplayer modes, and the overall tough as nails difficulty. I think I'll just sum up some things so you get an overall view of this game.
+a lot of diversity in landscapes
+a lot of diversity in traps
+♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t traps are rare. You won't be finding too much IWBTG ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.
+great soundtrack
+4 player co-op, or player vs player. Whether it's working together to complete a level, or trying to kill your opponents in deathmatch mode, I have had a great time doing so.
+there are cases where teamwork will help you. not everything you do is screw over other people.
-bad speedrunning system (you have to exit to the map and restart the level to restart all the traps)
-low resolution
-being able to jump on other people is fun at first, but it gets frustrating very quickly.
-various other flaws

overall this is a game I recommend for people who like difficult platformers, fans of super meat boy for example will easily play this game for hours.

This is probably going to be my final review update for this game as I don't believe any further patches are coming. On the off chance it does change though I will update this again, as I have done since March 2014.

Let's start with the TL;DR

Cons:
-You literally cannot get all of the achievements or 100% the game without hacking the game. It was brought to the attention of the devs 10 months ago as of today (April 12th 2014) and it has been acknowledged as needing to be fixed but it is still broken.
-The leaderboards, as always, are filled with hackers and impossible scores. Yay.
-Fireballs in later levels feel very unfair sometimes. They will often kill you even if you have the rest of the level down to a science.
-Level select is so tedious in singleplayer. There is no reason for it to be like this.
-Overly sensitive keyboard controls (prepare to take multiple steps when you lightly tap movement, causing you to walk off many edges and into many spikes). Similar issue with trying to do small jumps. You will just randomly jump high and smash into death traps.
-A lot of the level art looks like it was simply copy/pasted with a brush tool over and over...which I actually think it was but of course I can't verify that.
-Good music but you will be stuck on levels for so long that you will get absolutely sick of hearing it. So this is a bit of both categories.

Pros:
-Over 100 levels (counting the race levels) that get harder as you go along. Good for those who like a challenge. You will want to throw your controller at points so don't be surprise, that's the type of game it is.
-The 4 player online/offline co-op, which doesn't always work if you live really far away, can be very enjoyable because you can split the rage and success between you.
-Good music but you will be stuck on levels for so long that you will get absolutely sick of hearing it. So this is a bit of both categories.
-The devs are genuinely nice and are willing to offer advice and help if you get stuck.

Tight controls, lots of levels and very challenging. Recommend it if you like punishing platformers. I have one major and a couple of minor concerns with the game that makes it hard for me to recommend it at full price however:

Crouching mid-air
If you crouch by pressing down mid-air you lose the ability to steer and drop straight down. This means that touching down will kill you instantly on any jump or any time you need to dodge traps while falling down. The only explanation I can think of for this is preventing people from cheesing certain levels. It plays no part in any puzzle and has killed me more times than I can count.

The Overworld
I haven't found any way to skip between the worlds. Every time you start up the game you need to move through the entire game world to get to where you left off. A minor annoyance.

F you"-moments
Hidden blocks smashing you out of nowhere. Not a lot of these and you learn them quickly

reviewText:
Bloody Trapland is a hardcore platformer that encourages Cooperative play.

I only played this solo so I won't have that much to say on the multiplayer front.

The game itself is a simple platformer, the only real mechanics are jumping and crouching, however you can use your first jump as an air jump if you fall off a ledge. It is a very challenging game, and I was not able to complete the last level, however I was able to get there and play it for a while in about 5 hours. I feel like the playtime will mostly come from having to repeat the challenging levels over and over again. If you are not up to the challenge, this will probably just frustrate you.

The levels are designed well in that they will make you think very hard in how to approach the different parts of them, and you will get penalized heavily for making mistakes. The game is very cycle based, which is one of my main gripes about the game. If you aren't familiar with cycles, it basically is the concept of things being time based such as moving platforms. The game is full of traps, and a very large portion of them are on a time based system. Because the game is cooperative, the timers are always going, the level does not reset at any point. This can be extremely frustrating. It is normal for cycles to be in platform games, but here it adds to the challenge in an annoying way. Let's say you attempt to do a level right when you load in. You die because you were 2 seconds too fast getting to Trap A. Now you start the level 2 seconds later, however you die to trap B because you were 1 second too slow. This is a constant process of trial and error that becomes more obvious in later levels. There is still a large amount of normal platforming challenge, but I feel the emphasis on cycles as well as the tons of layered time based traps in later levels, adds to a game you will want to stop playing. I feel like this would be made impossible in coop play. Cooperative play would be very fun but I can't imagine you would enjoy it at the end of the game, where you have to make extremely careful decisions about cycles to move on.

There are also a few other multiplayer modes, but as I was playing this solo it wasn't really of interest to me. It still might be fun to try those out with some friends. There is also a level editor, which is always a really cool thing to have in games to keep things fresh and try out your ideas.

There is the main set of about 60 levels but there are also secret levels you can find which can be a neat way to get through worlds.

I don't think there is any story in the game. You're just a bunch of cats jumping around.

Pros
Cooperative Support
Very Challenging
Solid Platforming Mechanics
Large amount of levels including hidden worlds
Extra Multiplayer Game Modes
Level Editor

Cons
Unforgiving or downright impossible to casual players
Multiplayer might be more trouble then it's worth
Cycle Based Level Design
No Story

All in all I did enjoy the game, but I really hated having to watch the clock" per say just to beat levels. It made me want to stop when I got to the last level just because there were about 20 different timers I had to keep an eye on. If you have some friends that want a very difficult platforming experience

Tight controls, lots of levels and very challenging. Recommend it if you like punishing platformers. I have one major and a couple of minor concerns with the game that makes it hard for me to recommend it at full price however:

Crouching mid-air
If you crouch by pressing down mid-air you lose the ability to steer and drop straight down. This means that touching down will kill you instantly on any jump or any time you need to dodge traps while falling down. The only explanation I can think of for this is preventing people from cheesing certain levels. It plays no part in any puzzle and has killed me more times than I can count.

The Overworld
I haven't found any way to skip between the worlds. Every time you start up the game you need to move through the entire game world to get to where you left off. A minor annoyance.

F you"-moments
Hidden blocks smashing you out of nowhere. Not a lot of these and you learn them quickly
date:
but they deserve a (dis)honorable mention as not having random deaths is game design 101.

Multiplayer
